title: 103_s1231
content: The Act titled "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" simplifies employment taxes on domestic services. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code to set a threshold for social security taxes on cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" sets a threshold for social security taxes on cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home. The applicable dollar threshold is defined as the amount required for a quarter of coverage as determined under the Social Security Act for calendar year 1994. Adjustments to this amount will be made by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for subsequent years. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amends the Code to exclude domestic employees under 18 from coverage. It includes provisions for domestic service in a private home performed by individuals under 18. Conforming amendments are also made to the Code. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amends the Social Security Act to change the time period from calendar quarter to calendar year and adjust the dollar threshold for cash remuneration paid to employees for domestic service in a private home. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amends the Social Security Act to change the time period from calendar quarter to calendar year and adjust the dollar threshold for cash remuneration paid to employees for domestic service in a private home. Additionally, employment of domestic employees under age 18 is excluded from coverage under the Act. The amendments made by the "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" apply to remuneration paid in calendar years starting after December 31, 1994. Excluded employment includes services performed after December 31, 1994. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amendments apply to remuneration paid after December 31, 1994. Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to coordinate the collection of domestic service employment with income taxes. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amendments coordinate the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The "Social Security Domestic Employment Reform Act of 1993" amendments require returns for domestic service employment taxes to be filed on a calendar year basis by the 15th day of the 4th month following the employer's taxable year. No deposit requirements apply to these taxes, and they are subject to estimated tax provisions for the employer's taxable year. The employer must pay domestic service employment taxes in full by April 15th to avoid tax penalties. Adjustments may be made for annualization purposes, and transitional rules apply for tax calculations. The transitional rule for applying section 6654 to taxable years beginning in 1994-1995 increases the amount by 90% of the tax treated under paragraph (1) for the preceding year. Domestic service employment taxes include taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home and amounts withheld under section 3402(p), excluding service described in section 3121(g)(5). The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to domestic service employment taxes for employers liable for other employment taxes and the Secretary's authority to prescribe regulations. It also mentions the authority to enter agreements to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on domestic service employment. Taxes collected will be transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The Secretary can collect state unemployment taxes on domestic service employment under agreements, treating the collected amount as a tax imposed by chapter 23. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 25 of the Code. The amendments made by this subsection apply to remuneration paid after December 31, 1993. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide information to employers about their federal tax obligations for employees in domestic service, including potential obligations under state laws for unemployment insurance and workers compensation. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL DEBT COLLECTION PRACTICES. The Social Security Act is amended to allow the Secretary to use collection practices for delinquent amounts, defined as excess payments made to individuals over 18 years old that are deemed unrecoverable after they cease to be beneficiaries. This aligns with additional debt collection practices outlined in title 31 of the United States Code. The Social Security Act is amended to allow collection activities for delinquent amounts, with amendments applying to activities started after enactment of the Act and before October 1, 1999. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON PAYMENT OF BENEFITS TO CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS CONFINED BY COURT ORDER TO PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS. SEC. 4 prohibits the payment of benefits to individuals confined in public institutions by court order, regardless of their mental state or guilt of an offense. The amendment to the Social Security Act prohibits benefits for individuals confined in public institutions under the agency's jurisdiction. The effective date for these changes is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Nursing homes must report admissions of SSI recipients within 2 weeks to the Secretary for determinations under section 1611(e). Effective from October 1, 1995.
